title: Equity funds record net inflow, new PLI scheme soon, & more

news.title: Word of the day
news.description:
Bond price-yield relationship
Bonds are issued at a coupon rate that the issuer pays to the investor.
Once issued, the coupon rate never changes but the ‘yield’ (% gain from rise in price of the bond) changes with a rise or fall in the bond's price.
With a rise in rates by central banks, the yield rise. When central banks decrease the rates, the yields fall.
The way bonds work is complex and interesting. Do make sure you read more on this.

news.description:
Theme: tools to pick stocks
Day 2: Tuesday
Stocks graphs.
Whether you are a long-term inventor or a short-term trader, you will end up spending time looking at and analysing graphs of the stocks.
Graphs are the starting point of research for many.
Say there's a sudden rise on xyz date. You can then go and check why that happened.
Likewise, you can check how the stock price behaves on important dates like the dividend date, quarterly results date, etc.
This can help you understand how resilient a stock price is to certain events, which events affect that stock more, etc.
Example, when the markets were crashing in 2020, FMCG sector stocks were shooting up unlike other stocks.

news.title: Featured question
news.description:
"In ELSS Scheme after 3 year lock in period withdrawal amount will be taxable or not?"
Profits or gains from investing in ELSS funds is taxable.
It is paid only when you withdraw. Say you invest Rs 1.5 lakh in 2019. The lock-in ends in 2022. But you take out this money in 2025.
So you will have to pay a tax in 2025 only.
Also, it is on the gain or profit, not the entire amount.
There is a Rs 1 lakh exemption on gains from equity.
So only if your gains from equity (shares, equity mutual funds, ELSS, etc) in a given year is higher than Rs 1 lakh do you pay tax.
Otherwise, you pay Rs 0 in taxes (you still have to show it when you file your taxes).

Fact: Nifty has fallen between 1% and 2% about 110 times in the last 5 years.
